question: Why did early Christians meet in secret catacombs?

choices.text: They were hiding from Roman persecution
choices.explanation: Early Christians met in underground tunnels called catacombs because the Roman Empire persecuted them for their faith.

choices.text: They liked dark places
choices.explanation: Early Christians met in catacombs because the Roman Empire persecuted them. They needed safe, hidden places to worship.

choices.text: There were no churches yet
choices.explanation: While there were no church buildings yet, the main reason was that Romans persecuted Christians, so they met in secret underground tunnels.

question: How many apostles did Jesus choose?

choices.text: 12 apostles
choices.explanation: Jesus chose 12 apostles to be his closest followers and to spread his message.

choices.text: 7 apostles
choices.explanation: Jesus chose 12 apostles, not 7. The number 12 matched the 12 tribes of Israel.

choices.text: 3 apostles
choices.explanation: Jesus chose 12 apostles. While Peter, James, and John were especially close to Jesus, there were 12 in total.

question: What was the Apostle Peter's job before following Jesus?

choices.text: A fisherman
choices.explanation: Peter was a fisherman on the Sea of Galilee. Jesus told him he would become a fisher of men!

choices.text: A carpenter
choices.explanation: Peter was actually a fisherman, not a carpenter. Jesus himself was a carpenter before his ministry.

choices.text: A soldier
choices.explanation: Peter was a fisherman on the Sea of Galilee. He left his fishing nets behind when Jesus called him.

question: What did Jesus say was the greatest commandment?

choices.text: Love God and love each other
choices.explanation: Jesus taught that the greatest commandments are to love God with all your heart and to love your neighbor as yourself.

choices.text: Be the strongest warrior
choices.explanation: Jesus taught peace and love, not fighting. The greatest commandment is to love God and love each other.

choices.text: Collect as much gold as possible
choices.explanation: Jesus taught that love is more important than wealth. The greatest commandment is to love God and love each other.

question: Around what year does this adventure take place?

choices.text: 64 AD, during the Roman Empire
choices.explanation: This adventure takes place around 64 AD, when Emperor Nero ruled Rome and persecuted Christians.

choices.text: 1776 AD, during the American Revolution
choices.explanation: This story is set in 64 AD, during the time of the Roman Empire under Emperor Nero, over 1700 years before America!

choices.text: 1000 BC, before Jesus was born
choices.explanation: This story takes place in 64 AD, about 30 years after Jesus lived. The early Christians were spreading his teachings.

question: Who was the Roman Emperor who persecuted Christians?

choices.text: Emperor Nero
choices.explanation: Emperor Nero blamed Christians for the Great Fire of Rome in 64 AD and began persecuting them.

choices.text: Emperor Augustus
choices.explanation: Augustus ruled earlier. It was Emperor Nero who blamed Christians for the Great Fire of Rome and persecuted them.

choices.text: King David
choices.explanation: King David lived long before Rome. Emperor Nero was the ruler who persecuted Christians in 64 AD.

question: What did Apostle James teach about faith?

choices.text: Faith means doing good things, not just talking
choices.explanation: James taught that faith without actions is not complete. Showing kindness and helping others demonstrates real faith.

choices.text: Faith means staying quiet about what you believe
choices.explanation: James taught the opposite! He said faith means putting your beliefs into action by helping others and showing kindness.

choices.text: Faith only matters on special days
choices.explanation: James taught that faith is an everyday choice. It means showing love and kindness through your actions every day.

question: Jesus called Peter 'the rock.' What did he mean?

choices.text: Peter would be a strong foundation for the church
choices.explanation: Jesus meant that Peter would be strong and dependable, like a rock that others could build upon.

choices.text: Peter was very heavy
choices.explanation: It was not about weight! Jesus meant Peter would be a strong, reliable foundation for the church.

choices.text: Peter liked to collect rocks
choices.explanation: It was a metaphor! Jesus meant Peter would be strong and dependable, a solid foundation for the church.

question: Why did the Roman Empire persecute early Christians?

choices.text: Christians refused to worship the Roman gods and emperor
choices.explanation: Romans saw Christians as a threat because they worshiped only one God and refused to honor the emperor as divine.

choices.text: Christians were too noisy at night
choices.explanation: The real reason was that Christians refused to worship Roman gods and the emperor. Rome saw this as disloyal and dangerous.

choices.text: Christians did not pay their taxes
choices.explanation: Actually, Jesus taught to pay taxes. Rome persecuted Christians because they refused to worship the emperor and Roman gods.

question: What is a martyr?

choices.text: Someone who dies for their faith rather than give it up
choices.explanation: A martyr is someone who chooses to suffer or die rather than deny their beliefs. Many early Christians became martyrs.

choices.text: A type of Roman soldier
choices.explanation: A martyr is not a soldier. A martyr is someone who dies for their faith rather than deny what they believe.

choices.text: A person who builds churches
choices.explanation: A martyr is someone who suffers or dies for their faith. The word comes from Greek and means witness.

question: What did the fish symbol mean to early Christians?

choices.text: It was a secret sign to identify fellow Christians
choices.explanation: Christians drew the fish symbol (Ichthys) to secretly identify each other. One person would draw half, and the other would complete it.

choices.text: They really liked fishing
choices.explanation: The fish was a secret code! The Greek word for fish (Ichthys) spelled out Jesus Christ, God's Son, Savior.

choices.text: It was a Roman military symbol
choices.explanation: The fish was a Christian symbol, not Roman. The Greek letters in Ichthys stood for Jesus Christ, God's Son, Savior.

question: What does the Greek word Ichthys mean?

choices.text: Fish, and its letters stand for Jesus Christ, God's Son, Savior
choices.explanation: Ichthys means fish in Greek. Each letter stands for a word: Iesous Christos Theou Yios Soter — Jesus Christ, God's Son, Savior.

choices.text: It means love in Greek
choices.explanation: Ichthys means fish in Greek. The letters are an acronym: I-Ch-Th-Y-S stands for Jesus Christ, God's Son, Savior.

choices.text: It means church in Greek
choices.explanation: Ichthys means fish. Early Christians used it as a secret code because the letters stand for Jesus Christ, God's Son, Savior.

question: Why did early Christians meet in underground catacombs?

choices.text: To worship safely, hidden from Roman authorities
choices.explanation: Catacombs were underground burial tunnels. Christians met there in secret because gathering to worship was dangerous during persecution.

choices.text: Because they could not afford buildings
choices.explanation: The main reason was safety. Catacombs were underground tunnels where Christians could worship without being caught by Roman soldiers.

choices.text: Because catacombs were warmer in winter
choices.explanation: Christians met in catacombs to hide from persecution. These underground tunnels kept their gatherings secret from Roman authorities.

question: Who was Polycarp?

choices.text: A bishop who was martyred for refusing to deny Christ
choices.explanation: Polycarp was the Bishop of Smyrna who was a student of the Apostle John. He was martyred at age 86 for his faith.

choices.text: A Roman emperor who helped Christians
choices.explanation: Polycarp was not a Roman emperor. He was a Christian bishop, a student of Apostle John, who was martyred for his faith at age 86.

choices.text: The person who wrote the Bible
choices.explanation: Polycarp did not write the Bible. He was the Bishop of Smyrna who learned from Apostle John and was martyred at age 86.

question: What is the Nicene Creed?

choices.text: A statement of Christian beliefs agreed upon at the Council of Nicaea
choices.explanation: The Nicene Creed was written at the Council of Nicaea in 325 AD. It states the core beliefs that Christians share.

choices.text: A Roman law about taxes
choices.explanation: The Nicene Creed is not a law. It is a statement of faith written by church leaders at the Council of Nicaea in 325 AD.

choices.text: A type of ancient book
choices.explanation: A creed is a statement of beliefs, not a book. The Nicene Creed was agreed upon at the Council of Nicaea in 325 AD.

question: Why was the Council of Nicaea important?

choices.text: Church leaders gathered to agree on what Christians believe
choices.explanation: Emperor Constantine called the Council of Nicaea in 325 AD so church leaders could settle disagreements about core beliefs.

choices.text: It was a meeting to plan a war
choices.explanation: The Council of Nicaea was not about war. It was a meeting where church leaders agreed on the core beliefs of Christianity.

choices.text: It was a marketplace for trading goods
choices.explanation: Nicaea hosted a council, not a market. Over 300 bishops met to define what Christians believe about God and Jesus.

question: What is the Trinity?

choices.text: The belief that God is Father, Son, and Holy Spirit
choices.explanation: The Trinity is the Christian teaching that God exists as three persons in one: Father, Son (Jesus), and Holy Spirit.

choices.text: Three different gods
choices.explanation: The Trinity is not three gods. Christians believe in one God who exists as three persons: Father, Son, and Holy Spirit.

choices.text: A group of three Roman emperors
choices.explanation: The Trinity is a Christian belief, not a political group. It means God is one being in three persons: Father, Son, and Holy Spirit.

question: Who was Athanasius?

choices.text: A bishop who defended the belief that Jesus is truly God
choices.explanation: Athanasius was the Bishop of Alexandria who fought to preserve the teaching that Jesus is fully God, not a lesser being.

choices.text: A Roman emperor who banned Christianity
choices.explanation: Athanasius was not an emperor. He was a brave bishop who defended the belief that Jesus is truly God, even when it was unpopular.

choices.text: The person who built the first church
choices.explanation: Athanasius did not build the first church. He was a bishop who defended the core Christian belief that Jesus is fully divine.

question: What did Arius teach that the church disagreed with?

choices.text: That Jesus was created by God and was not equal to God
choices.explanation: Arius taught that Jesus was a created being, not equal to God. The Council of Nicaea declared this teaching was wrong.

choices.text: That people should be kind to each other
choices.explanation: Everyone agreed on kindness! The disagreement was about whether Jesus is equal to God. Arius said no, the council said yes.

choices.text: That the Bible should be read aloud
choices.explanation: The dispute was about the nature of Jesus. Arius taught Jesus was not equal to God, which the Council of Nicaea rejected.

question: Why do churches recite creeds?

choices.text: To remember and declare what they believe together
choices.explanation: Creeds help Christians remember their shared beliefs. Saying them together unites believers across the world and through history.

choices.text: Because it is a magic spell
choices.explanation: Creeds are not magic. They are statements of belief that help Christians remember and declare their faith together.

choices.text: To make services longer
choices.explanation: Creeds are not about filling time. They are important statements that unite Christians by declaring their shared beliefs.

question: The Creed says Jesus is 'of one being with the Father.' What does that mean?

choices.text: Jesus shares the same divine nature as God the Father
choices.explanation: Of one being means Jesus is not separate from God. He shares the same divine nature — fully God, not a lesser created being.

choices.text: Jesus and God are the same person with no differences
choices.explanation: They share the same nature but are distinct persons. The Father and Son are both fully God but are not identical persons.

choices.text: Jesus was adopted by God later
choices.explanation: The Creed teaches Jesus was always divine, not adopted. 'Of one being' means he shares God's nature from eternity.

question: What is Augustine's book 'Confessions' about?

choices.text: His journey from a sinful life to following Christ
choices.explanation: Augustine's Confessions tells how he lived a wild youth but eventually found God through honest searching and prayer.

choices.text: A guide to building churches
choices.explanation: Confessions is not about buildings. It is Augustine's personal story of turning from sin to faith in God.

choices.text: A list of Roman laws
choices.explanation: Confessions is not about laws. It is Augustine's honest story of how he found God after years of searching.

question: What was Jerome's most important work?

choices.text: Translating the Bible into Latin, called the Vulgate
choices.explanation: Jerome spent about 15 years translating the Bible into Latin so ordinary people could read God's word in their language.

choices.text: Painting pictures of saints
choices.explanation: Jerome was a scholar, not a painter. His greatest work was translating the Bible into Latin, known as the Vulgate.

choices.text: Building the first monastery
choices.explanation: Jerome did not build the first monastery. He translated the Bible into Latin (the Vulgate) so more people could read it.

question: What did Ambrose do when Emperor Theodosius ordered a massacre?

choices.text: He refused the emperor communion until he repented
choices.explanation: Ambrose bravely told the emperor that even rulers must answer to God. Theodosius eventually repented publicly.

choices.text: He praised the emperor for being strong
choices.explanation: Ambrose did not praise violence. He bravely confronted the emperor and refused him communion until he repented.

choices.text: He ran away and hid
choices.explanation: Ambrose showed great courage. He stood up to the most powerful man in the world and demanded he repent.

question: What is a 'Church Father'?

choices.text: An early Christian teacher whose writings shaped the faith
choices.explanation: Church Fathers were influential early Christian leaders and writers. Their teachings helped define what Christians believe.

choices.text: The father of a church building
choices.explanation: Church Father does not mean someone who owns a building. It refers to early Christian teachers whose writings shaped the faith.

choices.text: A Roman official who controlled churches
choices.explanation: Church Fathers were not Roman officials. They were devoted Christian teachers who helped explain and defend the faith.

question: What did Augustine teach in 'City of God'?

choices.text: God's kingdom is greater and more lasting than any earthly empire
choices.explanation: Augustine wrote City of God after Rome fell. He taught that God's eternal kingdom matters more than any earthly power.

choices.text: How to build a perfect city on earth
choices.explanation: City of God is not an architecture guide. Augustine taught that God's eternal kingdom is greater than any earthly empire.

choices.text: That Rome would last forever
choices.explanation: Augustine wrote City of God after Rome fell! He taught that earthly kingdoms fall, but God's kingdom lasts forever.

question: Why was Latin important to the early church?

choices.text: It was the common language of the Roman world
choices.explanation: Latin was spoken across the Roman Empire. Translating the Bible into Latin meant millions more people could understand it.

choices.text: It was a secret code that only priests knew
choices.explanation: Latin was not a secret code. It was the everyday language of the Roman world, which is why Jerome translated the Bible into it.

choices.text: It sounded prettier than other languages
choices.explanation: The reason was practical: Latin was the common language of the Roman Empire, so translating the Bible into it reached more people.

question: Why is courage important in the Christian faith?

choices.text: Sometimes standing for truth requires bravery against powerful opposition
choices.explanation: Like Ambrose confronting an emperor, Christians sometimes need courage to stand for what is right, even when it is difficult.

choices.text: Christians must be the strongest fighters
choices.explanation: Christian courage is not about physical fighting. It is about bravely standing for truth and justice, like Ambrose did.

choices.text: Courage is not really needed for faith
choices.explanation: Courage is essential! Early Christians faced persecution. Ambrose showed courage by confronting an emperor for wrongdoing.

question: What was the purpose of early Christian monasteries?

choices.text: Places for prayer, study, and preserving knowledge
choices.explanation: Monasteries were communities where monks devoted their lives to prayer, studying Scripture, and copying important books by hand.

choices.text: Forts for fighting wars
choices.explanation: Monasteries were not military forts. They were peaceful communities devoted to prayer, study, and preserving knowledge.

choices.text: Marketplaces for selling goods
choices.explanation: Monasteries were not markets. Monks lived simple lives focused on prayer, study, and carefully copying books by hand.

question: What is the Chi-Rho symbol?

choices.text: The first two Greek letters of Christ's name, used as a Christian symbol
choices.explanation: Chi (X) and Rho (P) are the first two letters of Christos in Greek. Constantine saw this symbol in a vision before battle.

choices.text: A Roman military flag
choices.explanation: The Chi-Rho is not a military flag. It combines the first two Greek letters of Christ's name and became a powerful Christian symbol.

choices.text: An ancient Egyptian hieroglyph
choices.explanation: The Chi-Rho is Greek, not Egyptian. It combines X (Chi) and P (Rho), the first letters of Christ in Greek.

question: What did the Edict of Milan do?

choices.text: It allowed Christians to worship freely and ended official persecution
choices.explanation: In 313 AD, Emperor Constantine issued the Edict of Milan, granting religious freedom throughout the Roman Empire.

choices.text: It banned all religions except Christianity
choices.explanation: The Edict of Milan did not ban other religions. It granted freedom to ALL religions, including Christianity.

choices.text: It created a new Roman city
choices.explanation: The Edict of Milan was about religious freedom. It ended the persecution of Christians in the Roman Empire in 313 AD.

question: What did Constantine see before the Battle of Milvian Bridge?

choices.text: A vision of the cross with the words 'In this sign, conquer'
choices.explanation: Constantine reported seeing a cross of light in the sky with the Latin words 'In hoc signo vinces' — In this sign, you shall conquer.

choices.text: A vision of a golden eagle
choices.explanation: Constantine saw a cross, not an eagle. The vision came with the words 'In this sign, conquer' and led him to adopt Christianity.

choices.text: A vision of the sea parting
choices.explanation: That was Moses! Constantine saw a cross of light with the message 'In this sign, conquer' before winning the battle.

question: Why was Constantine important to the history of Christianity?

choices.text: He was the first Roman emperor to support Christianity
choices.explanation: Constantine ended centuries of persecution and made it safe for Christians to worship openly. He also called the Council of Nicaea.

choices.text: He wrote the Bible
choices.explanation: Constantine did not write the Bible. He was important because he was the first emperor to support Christianity and end persecution.

choices.text: He was one of the twelve apostles
choices.explanation: Constantine lived nearly 300 years after the apostles. He was the first Roman emperor to support and protect Christians.
